bugs.title: Can't start Kdump with SecureBoot enabled

bugzilla.short_desc: Can't start Kdump with SecureBoot enabled

long_desc.thetext:

See "systemctl status kdump.service" and "journalctl -xe" for details.

Additional info:

4.8.6-300.fc25.x86_64 works well

4.11.9-200.fc25 does not work, fc26 kernels also do not work.

But boot with 4.8.6-300.fc25 and then kexec -s -l other any Fedora kernels works just fine.

Kexec -s -l will verify the kernel signature but probably the running kernel does not has the keys to verify it or some code bug, I'm not sure. Maybe some Fedora kernel changes or upstream changes caused this..

For reference purpose, below upstream fixes fixed this issue:

commit ea93102f32244e3f45c8b26260be77ed0cc1d16c
Author: Yannik Sembritzki <yannik@sembritzki.me>
Date:   Thu Aug 16 14:05:23 2018 +0100

    Fix kexec forbidding kernels signed with keys in the secondary keyring to boot
    
commit 817aef260037f33ee0f44c17fe341323d3aebd6d
Author: Yannik Sembritzki <yannik@sembritzki.me>

bugzilla.short_desc: [abrt] rcu_exp_wait_wake: WARNING: CPU: 0 PID: 10705 at net/mac80211/util.c:1863 ieee80211_reconfig+0x7d/0x12b0 [mac80211]

long_desc.thetext:
Description of problem:
after just a few minutes, the wifi connection fails and the notebook locks up compeltly.

* start the notebook
* login
* start wifi
* wait for 2-3 minutes until wifi is gone
* use the wifi "turn off" functione in the gnome gui
* use the "turn on"

now everything is blocked. only a hard powercycle helps.

The wifi worked on Fedora 27. But also had issues with the wifi but turn off/on made it work  again.

since 4.16.9-300.fc28.x86_64 I haven't seen this error anymore. Wifi was stable since the upgrade.

Created attachment 1440522
dmesg before crash

This is how it happens to me:
1. wifi looses the current network (appears on the gui as if it were connected but with zero bars on the signal strength indicator)
2. turn wifi off
3. turn wifi on again ---> the system hangs completely

Attaching a dmesg log for the wifi after stage 1 already happened. (But before crashing my system.) The interesting part seems to be this:
[30372.900832] wlp2s0: AP 64:7c:34:3f:c3:b0 changed bandwidth, new config is 2437 MHz, width 2 (2447/0 MHz)

Searching a bit in kernel sources, this message is printed by this line:
https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/net/mac80211/mlme.c#L364
And width 2 seems to correspond to NL80211_CHAN_WIDTH_40 here:
https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/include/uapi/linux/nl80211.h#L3880

So it seems that either the driver or the firmware can't cope with it when the AP changes the bandwidth.

Now I upgraded to 4.17-rc6 and also updated the firmware to the latest from the manufacturer. Will report back about whether this helps or not.

I tested with some other wireless APs in the past few days.

While it does reduce the frequency of the crashes, they did not go away completely. Now it can survive some bandwidth changes, but eventually some very similar backtraces start to crop up in the journal, along with firmware crashes...

So the problem is not really solved.

I can reliably reproduce the problem by simulating some firmware hard crashes like this:

echo hard > /sys/kernel/debug/ieee80211/phy0/ath10k/simulate_fw_crash

On my machine the issue always occours after 3 such simulated crashes. I would expect that a single driver crash should not affect the whole
system like this, but it does.

was ok: kernel 4.16.11-300.fc28.x86_64
failing again: kernel 4.16.12-300.fc28.x86_64

I've discussed this issue with the ath10k driver maintainers.
Here is the relevant thread:
http://lists.infradead.org/pipermail/ath10k/2018-May/011534.html

It boils down to two problems:
1. When the AP changes bandwidth, the firmware crashes
2. After the firmware crashes a number of times the driver is unable to recover and takes the entire system down with it

Number 1 is fixed by this patch:
http://lists.infradead.org/pipermail/ath10k/2018-June/011582.html

I've been running a custom-built kernel, basically applied the patch to Fedora's kernel 4.17 package, and can confirm that the ath10k firmware no longer crashes when the AP changes bandwidth.

Now giving it a try on the latest 4.17 version (which is no longer RC), and if it works, I will send a pull request to the Fedora kernel package on pagure.

Since the maintainer has not yet accepted the patch: there is also a workaround: in your wireless AP's settings, change the bandwidth to a constant value. For example, change it from "20 MHz / 40 MHz" to just "20 MHz" - that way it won't try to change the bandwidth, hence this issue will not be triggered.

(In reply to Chad Feller from comment #28)
> Description of problem:
> Occurred during system startup.
> 
> Version-Release number of selected component:
> kernel-core-4.18.7-200.fc28

Seeing which bug report this was attached to, I think this was actually triggered during the previous system boot.  That is, I was having network connectivity issues, so I rebooted to alleviate the issue and this bug report was waiting for me on login.

That said, I've had about a dozen network crashes and freezes with kernel 4.18.5 and 4.18.7, with numerous firmware crashes and network devices restarts littering the logs.  The desktop becomes choppy and almost unusable until a reboot happens.  All but one of the bug reports this past week have been unreportable due to what ABRT claims is a tainted kernel or a backtrace that has insufficient information.  I suspect that most of those unreportable issues somehow relate back to this one. 

It is frustrating that this problem has gotten worse, not better, so I find myself turning off wifi and just using a wired connection more often than not.

Description of problem:
I have no idea;  It happened around the time when I was logging into my home wireless network for the first time.

I clicked on my wireless network ID, entered the password, and the "Oops!" crash report appeared shortly after my login
to the wireless failed.

bugs.title: CVE-2018-12232 kernel: NULL pointer dereference if close and fchownat system calls share a socket file descriptor [fedora-all]

bugzilla.short_desc: CVE-2018-12232 kernel: NULL pointer dereference if close and fchownat system calls share a socket file descriptor [fedora-all]

blocked.short_desc: CVE-2018-12232 kernel: NULL pointer dereference if close and fchownat system calls share a socket file descriptor

long_desc.thetext:
A NULL pointer dereference issue was found in the Linux kernel. If the close() and fchownat() system calls share a socket file descriptor as an argument, then the two calls can race and trigger a NULL pointer dereference leading to a system crash and a denial of service.

References:

https://lkml.org/lkml/2018/6/5/14

https://marc.info/?t=152817459500001&r=1&w=2

https://patchwork.ozlabs.org/patch/926519/

An upstream patch:

https://git.kernel.org/pub/scm/linux/kernel/git/torvalds/linux.git/commit/?id=6d8c50dcb029872b298eea68cc6209c866fd3e14

Created kernel tracking bugs for this issue:

Affects: fedora-all [bug 1590216]

This issue has been addressed in the following products:

  Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7

Via RHSA-2018:2948 https://access.redhat.com/errata/RHSA-2018:2948

This is an automatically created tracking bug!  It was created to ensure
that one or more security vulnerabilities are fixed in affected versions
of fedora-all.

For comments that are specific to the vulnerability please use bugs filed
against the "Security Response" product referenced in the "Blocks" field.

For more information see:
http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Security/TrackingBugs

When submitting as an update, use the fedpkg template provided in the next
comment(s).  This will include the bug IDs of this tracking bug as well as
the relevant top-level CVE bugs.

Please also mention the CVE IDs being fixed in the RPM changelog and the
fedpkg commit message.

NOTE: this issue affects multiple supported versions of Fedora. While only
one tracking bug has been filed, please correct all affected versions at
the same time.  If you need to fix the versions independent of each other,
you may clone this bug as appropriate.
